articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — Connecticut is back at No. 1 in the AP Top 25 to start its repeat bid in March Madness; Houston, Purdue, Iowa State next.
articles.title: Connecticut is back at No. 1 in the AP Top 25 to start its repeat bid in March Madness; Houston, Purdue, Iowa State next

articles.author: WAFAA SHURAFA, SAMY MAGDY and TIA GOLDENBERG
articles.description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — The U.N. food agency said Monday that “famine is imminent” in northern Gaza, where 70% of the remaining population is experiencing catastrophic hunger, and that a further escalation of the war could push around half of Gaza's total population to the brink of starvation.
articles.title: UN says 'famine is imminent' in northern Gaza as Israel launches another raid on the main hospital

articles.author: AAMER MADHANI, ZEKE MILLER and JULIA FRANKEL
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke on Monday, their first interaction in more than a month, as the divide has grown between allies over the food crisis in Gaza and conduct of the war, according to the White House.
articles.title: Biden and Netanyahu hold first call in more than a month as tension grows over food crisis, war

articles.author: EMMA BURROWS, DASHA LITVINOVA and JIM HEINTZ
articles.description: President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring Monday his determination to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
articles.title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era

articles.author: KIRSTEN GRIESHABER
articles.description: BERLIN (AP) — When Sabine Thonke joined a recent demonstration in Berlin against Germany's far-right party, it was the first time in years she felt hopeful that the growing power of the extremists in her country could be stopped.
articles.title: Germans thought they were immune to nationalism after confronting their Nazi past. They were wrong

articles.author: NICK PERRY and LISA RATHKE
articles.description: ELMORE, Vt. (AP) — Julie wants more donations to the food pantry. Kipp is busy knitting a sweater. Shorty is ready to ask: Why is so much being spent on a truck? The coffee, fresh-baked bread and donuts have been laid out.
articles.title: In Vermont, 'Town Meeting' is democracy embodied. What can the rest of the country learn from it?

articles.author: JONATHAN J. COOPER
articles.description: The lack of excitement many Americans feel about a presidential rematch has heightened interest in alternatives to the major-party candidates, none more so than Robert F.
articles.title: Who is Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and why is he running for president?

articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Supreme Court seemed likely Monday to side with the Biden administration in a dispute with Republican-led states over how far the federal government can go to combat controversial social media posts on topics including COVID-19 and election security.
articles.title: Supreme Court seems favorable to Biden administration over efforts to combat social media posts

articles.author: PIERRE-RICHARD LUXAMA and ODELYN JOSEPH
articles.description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) — Gangs attacked two upscale neighborhoods in Haiti’s capital early Monday in a rampage that left at least a dozen people dead in surrounding areas.Gunmen looted homes in the communities of Laboule and Thomassin before sunrise, forcing residents to flee as some called radio stations pleading for police.
articles.title: Gangs unleash new attacks on upscale areas in Haiti's capital, with at least a dozen killed nearby

articles.author: MATTHEW DALY
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday announced a comprehensive ban on asbestos, a carcinogen that is still used in some chlorine bleach, brake pads and other products and that kills tens of thousands of Americans every year.
articles.title: EPA bans asbestos, a deadly carcinogen still in use decades after a partial ban was enacted
